exds¶

Entry point for manipulating ExperimentalDatasets (ExDs). Provides the following operations:

exds_operations.op_list(exds_names) Print a table of the ExDs definitions known to MBFF.
exds_operations.op_build(exds_names) Build the specified ExDs, if they haven’t been previously built.
exds_operations.op_rebuild(exds_names) Rebuilds the specified ExDs, if the ExDs have been already built and are not locked.
exds_operations.op_resave(exds_names) Load already built ExDs from their folders, then immediately save them.
exds_operations.op_delete(exds_names) Completely delete built ExDs by deleting their folder, if they are not locked.
exds_operations.op_lock(exds_names) Lock the specified ExDs, thus preventing any writing operation to them.
exds_operations.op_unlock(exds_names) Unlock the specified ExDs, thus allowing any writing operation to them.
exds_operations.op_stats_print(exds_names) Deprecated, will be moved to the entry-point analysis_exds.
exds_operations.op_stats_regenerate(exds_names) Deprecated, will be moved to the entry-point analysis_exds.
exds_operations.op_stats_print_to_csv(exds_names) Deprecated, will be moved to the entry-point analysis_exds.
exds_operations.op_build_ks_gamma(exds_names) Build the KS gamma tables for the specified ExDs.
exds_operations.op_custom(exds_names, arguments) Invoke a custom operation.

More detailed descriptions of these operations are found in Defined operations.

Examples:

  • ./exds.py list all prints a table with all known ExDs definitions.
  • ./exds.py build -et TextProcessingDS GeneticDS will build all ExDs which have the tags TextProcessing or GeneticDS.
  • ./exds.py lock reuters_large_200 will lock the folder of the ExDs named reuters_large_200, preventing it from being rebuilt or deleted.
  • ./exds.py build_ks_gamma --build-ks-gamma-table-for-target=2 --build-ks-gamma-optimization=off genetic_100_B will will build the KS gamma table for the objective variable 2, without optimization, for the dataset genetic_100_B.
exds.create_argument_parser()[source]¶

Instantiates and configures an ArgumentParser.

exds.get_exds_names_from_arguments(arguments)[source]¶

Resolve the targets argument to actual ExDs definition names, based on targets_type.

See Command-line usage.

exds.entry_point_exds()[source]¶

Main function of the entry-point exds.

Invokes the corresponding operation on the ExDs specified as targets. See Defined operations.

Command-line usage¶

usage: exds [-h] [-n PARALLELISM]
            [--build-ks-gamma-optimization BUILD_KS_GAMMA_OPTIMIZATION]
            [--build-ks-gamma-table-for-target BUILD_KS_GAMMA_TABLE_FOR_TARGET]
            [-e | -el | -elf | -et] [--lock-exds | --lock-ks-gamma]
            [-p | -r | -c]
            {list,build,rebuild,resave,delete,lock,unlock,stats,build-ks-gamma,custom}
            targets [targets ...]

Positional Arguments¶

operation

Possible choices: list, build, rebuild, resave, delete, lock, unlock, stats, build-ks-gamma, custom

The operation to be performed on the targets.

Default: “list”

targets

The targets of the operation. What these targets are is controlled by the flags that affect the targets_type setting.

Default: [‘all’]

Named Arguments¶

-n, --parallelism
 Default: 1
--build-ks-gamma-optimization
 Default: “full_sharing”
--build-ks-gamma-table-for-target
 Default: -1
-e, --as_names

Indicates that the targets are ExDs names. This sets targets_type=names.

Default: “names”

-el, --as_exds_lists
 

Indicates that the targets are the ExDs from the specified ExDs lists. This sets targets_type=exds_lists.

Default: “names”

-elf, --as_exds_list_files
 

Indicates that the targets are the ExDs from the specified exdslist files. This sets targets_type=exds_list_files.

Default: “names”

-et, --as_exds_tags
 

Indicates that the targets are the ExDs with the given tags. This sets targets_type=exds_tags.

Default: “names”

--lock-exds Default: “exds”
--lock-ks-gamma
 Default: “exds”
-p, --print

Print stats.

Default: “print”

-r, --regenerate
 

Load the ExDs, recalculate stats and resave them to their own folders.

Default: “print”

-c, --print-to-csv
 

Load ExDs stats and convert them to CSV.

Default: “print”

Defined operations¶

Each ExDs operation is represented by a callback with the conventional name op_[OperationName]. Each such callback receives a list of ExDs definition names, representing the ExDs to act on.

exds_operations.op_list(exds_names)[source]¶

Print a table of the ExDs definitions known to MBFF.

See Dataset infrastructure on how to write ExDs definitions.

exds_operations.op_build(exds_names)[source]¶

Build the specified ExDs, if they haven’t been previously built.

Building a dataset implies creating a corresponding folder in the ExperimentalDatasets folder, then processing the source information, aggregating it and saving it in the format specified by the ExDs definition.

The difference between build and rebuild is that build will not overwrite an existing ExDs, whereas rebuild will never create an ExDs - it will only rebuild it if it already exists. These two separate commands exist mainly to prevent accidental overwriting of existing ExDs.

See experimental_dataset.build_experimental_dataset().

exds_operations.op_rebuild(exds_names)[source]¶

Rebuilds the specified ExDs, if the ExDs have been already built and are not locked.

If the ExDs haven’t yet been built, do nothing. Useful when building the ExDs is an operation involving randomness or when the ExDs must be saved in a new format, during development.

The difference between build and rebuild is that build will not overwrite an existing ExDs, whereas rebuild will never create an ExDs - it will only rebuild it if it already exists. These two separate commands exist mainly to prevent accidental overwriting of existing ExDs.

See experimental_dataset.build_experimental_dataset().

exds_operations.op_resave(exds_names)[source]¶

Load already built ExDs from their folders, then immediately save them.

This operation is useful during development, when an existing ExDs must be converted from an older format into a newer one, without having to rebuild it.

exds_operations.op_delete(exds_names)[source]¶

Completely delete built ExDs by deleting their folder, if they are not locked.

A deleted ExDs must be built again from its definition if it is to be used again.

exds_operations.op_lock(exds_names)[source]¶

Lock the specified ExDs, thus preventing any writing operation to them.

A locked ExDs must first be unlocked before rebuilding, resaving or deleting it.

An alternative locking operation is locking the already-built KS gamma tables. This is performed by adding the flag --lock-ks-gamma to the lock operation. Note that locking the KS gamma tables will not lock the entire ExDs. The two operations are separate.

exds_operations.op_unlock(exds_names)[source]¶

Unlock the specified ExDs, thus allowing any writing operation to them.

A locked ExDs must first be unlocked before rebuilding, resaving or deleting it.

An alternative unlocking operation is unlocking the already-built KS gamma tables, if they were previously locked. This is performed by adding the flag --lock-ks-gamma to the unlock operation. Note that unlocking the KS gamma tables will not unlock the entire ExDs. The two operations are separate.

exds_operations.op_stats_print(exds_names)[source]¶

Deprecated, will be moved to the entry-point analysis_exds.

exds_operations.op_stats_regenerate(exds_names)[source]¶

Deprecated, will be moved to the entry-point analysis_exds.

exds_operations.op_stats_print_to_csv(exds_names)[source]¶

Deprecated, will be moved to the entry-point analysis_exds.

exds_operations.op_build_ks_gamma(exds_names)[source]¶

Build the KS gamma tables for the specified ExDs.

By default, this operation builds the gamma tables for all the objective variables in the ExDs. An explicit objective variable can be specified using the option --build-ks-gamma-table-for-target=T, where T is a number, which means that only the gamma table for the objective variable T will be built.

exds_operations.op_custom(exds_names, arguments)[source]¶

Invoke a custom operation.

See exds_operations_custom.

Custom operations¶

Utility functions¶

A collection of functions required by multiple operations defined in the exds_operations module.

exds_operations_utilities.map_over_exds_definitions(exds_names, opname, op, print_status=True)[source]¶

Apply the callback op on the specified ExDs.

This function collects the definitions of the ExDs specified in exds_names, then calls op(definition) for all of them, while collecting the return values of each call.

exds_operations_utilities.map_over_exds_definitions_parallel(exds_names, opname, op, print_status=True)[source]¶

Apply the callback op on the specified ExDs in parallel.

This function collects the definitions of the ExDs specified in exds_names, then calls op(definition) for all of them, while collecting the return values of each call. The individual calls of op(definition) are performed by worker-processes. Process handling is done using multiprocessing.Pool.

The actual function run by the worker-processes is map_over_exds_definitions_single().

The number of worker-processes spawned is controlled by the option --parallelism.

exds_operations_utilities.map_over_exds_definitions_single(args)[source]¶

Apply an ExDs operation callback on a single ExDs definition.

This is the function run by the worker-processes spawned by map_over_exds_definitions_parallel().

exds_operations_utilities.exds_definition_table_format_string()[source]¶

Return a format string for a single row of the table printed by exds_operations.op_list().

exds_operations_utilities.exds_definition_table_header()[source]¶

Return a formatted string containing the header of the table printed by exds_operations.op_list().

exds_operations_utilities.exds_definition_to_table_string(definition)[source]¶

Return a row representing the ExDs definition in the table printed by exds_operations.op_list().
